comments.commentBody:
I'm a Democrat, but I say Bravo to Senator Brown for coming forward. The majority of men who have been sexually abused NEVER come forward.

Brown is being applauded for breaking his silence on websites for male survivors all over the world, like www.malesurvivor.org.

This discussion becomes more interesting as it progresses.

Rather than require that all new residential construction include fire sprinklers, why not require that individuals provide their own sprinkler, complete with water tank. The setup could be pushed from room to room in a small cart and could accompany people to work, shopping and on dates. This would cut building costs and promote individual responsibility in the process. A sure win-win.

The costs in medical expenses and lives lost in pedestrian accidents could be cut dramatically with individual airbags. These could be worn like a scuba suit and would provide sauna-like workouts every day of the week. If someone’s idiot kid with a learner’s permit taps you at an intersection, poof, and there you go bouncing down the street unharmed. Expensive at first, prices would drop as the economy of scale kicked in.

More children lose their lives in residential swimming pools than by gun accidents at home. Several states require firearms to be locked up when not in use. Why not require that all home swimming and wading pools be covered by a steel cage when not in use? The cost of vinyl pools will rise substantially and the average suburban neighborhood would look like a zoo most of the time but, hey, it can save young lives at millions of dollars a pop.

The key to resolving this issue is creativity. A little free association can come up with all kinds of solutions to save lives, boost the economy and energize the chattering classes.

Absurd!  Assume the average person makes $50,000 a year, and that they work for 40 years.  That comes to the market valuing that person at $2 million. $5 million?  It may be politically correct, but it is absurd!  This sort of arithmetic can bankrupt a country's government and make employing people in that country a fiscal impossibility.

But if a human life is worth one of these numbers, let's say $6M, the total spend under ALL of these efforts should be around that much, not for just one effort. If we spend $6M on three different efforts that affect an overlapping set of people we are spending much more than that one person...$18M, never mind 50 efforts.

These are some of the hidden costs that make everything here more expensive.

I still remember the bag phone, and enjoyed the years of phones getting smaller so a properly dressed gentleman could have one about him inconspicuously. As our phones grow we will be carrying purses soon just to keep our phone in. I still prefer a phone just for speaking. I have lost or broken a good many hand held phones, once running over it with my own car, and the loss was trivial. It it were my entire capacity of my laptop while I am on a trip, it would be a remarkably messy circumstance.
I would not have chosen that name, since as a computer it connotes obsolescence, given that the G4 is a two generation old Mac. It my proclaim a bit of extra dash as a phone, which is it? Phone or computer?

I'm guessing being a customer of good-old American know-how, specifically Boeing subsidiary Narus's "security solution" NarusInsight, with its "deep-packet inspection," real-time monitoring and interception capabilities and other features attractive to a totalitarian government, didn't hurt a bit.
Now that's the most exciting idea I've seen in a long time. I think I'll wait for the sequel.

The above are correct. Watson buzzed in faster, I suspect by order.  Time and again (I watched all three programs) faster and lost consistently when it lost control of the next question.  This was, at best, a ninety minute paid-for infomercial, and if IBM needs infomercials, I suggest they go back to the drawing board.

To all you disgruntled humans venting your spleen against Watson, remember that all these comments are eventually going to go into a future computer's memory bank. Why needlessly provoke your future masters?

It's merely a Watson, not a Sherlock Holmes, whose powers of observation and multimodal logic are nonverbal , beyond the recorded natural language on which Watson did its inquiry. To perceive the physical world, interpret it, and then assign to one's observations the labels and descriptors of natural human language -- that is the real stuff of thought.
Watson failed to play Jeopardy.  Make him listen to the reading of the answer, then allow him to buzz in.  Giving him the question is parsed text voided the competition before it got started.

Regardless how fast a computer is or how deep is its storehouse of pre-programed information, it will never be able to do what the human mind does quite easily - take the "intuitive leap" given several disparate facts. That is what true human genius is and what computers will never be able to do.
This guy is one of the most infamous "one drop" advocates and uses his academic ivy tower to constantly attack the multiracial movement.

How one box only, "American"?  This racist obsession with labels is maddening.  The Europeans have discovered what a national catastrophe "diversity" is. (as we did at the disgraceful Muslim attack on Ft Hood).  How about we make any reference to race in the selection of anything a crime?  Let me man or woman be judged by merit alone?  What a concept!
As govts tell people to feed ethanol to their SUVs that same program starves people and drives up the cost of meat. Quite the deal with the devil.

Don't neglect the impact of millions of small farmers being forced to move to cities by large subsidized farms which beat their prices.  The small sustainable farm produces 3 to 5 times more food--and better food--per acre.  Forcing them out helps create the shortage.  The vast amount of wasted resources in industrial farming, the vast distances the food travels, and the depletion and destruction that result, are at the root of the problem.  Subsidize small farmers worldwide instead, and buy local.
I agree with those who think that  the food supplies are not keeping up with the increase in population

Atmospheric changes on land and ocean need reciprocal changes in our efforts to turn the tide in our favour. Governments everywhere need to revise their attitudes towards their roles as governing bodies : their sincere and sensible ways to deal with crises, natural or man-made, is of utmost significance in providing leadership to the civilian masses to do their bit. Corrupt governments tend to generate disillusionment and cynicism in society which, in turn, result in the general acceptance of corruption as such, only to make matters worse.

Too bad most people are so heavily invested, temporally and financially, in the rat race - rats have never been noted for producing their own food. But I suppose even once we've eaten ourselves out of house and planet (our 1.4 billion cattle help us in that respect by eating about as much as 10 billion humans), we'll still be chewing the fat on the onerous debt, er, legally-entered-into contracts, that put us there.

But at least we won't have to get our hands dirty implementing taxes on things like meat, sugar, salt or fat, or even using implements like garden forks. By the sweat of my brow? Not in my back yard...
what about the possibility that protein is being hoarded as hedge against inflation i.e. wheat corn whatever are like gold, a reserve currency in the making?

The developed nations continue to perpetrate lie to the Asian populous nations that "your population is your biggest asset". Nothing wrong in it, except the Asian nations believe it!! Coming from India, I see what amounts we waste - be it food or water. The US should take a lead and ask populous nations to contain birth rates instead of lying to them. Only then will they be able to survive - and US will be able to survive. Now see China - if they buy wheat at higher prices (yes, they can afford to), cereal rates will go up in the US!! But on the other hand, if China were, maybe half of what it is now in terms of population, they would not even need to import.

Consider also the fact that many new types of crop that yield twice an year instead of once an year. This is also fast depleting soil fertility, as also the use of fertilizers. Floods erode top soil to a great extent. Any flooded land loses a good percentage of its fertility.

The only way to compensate that is by lowering the fertility of human beings. In all Asian countries, the lower strata of population (largely Muslims) breed like rabbits. Is there any hope for the world?!

Unless the wealthy nations that control the fundamentally flawed economic system and its continued perpetuation, implement some fast needed reforms, amenability, some tough rules regulation to control this greed creed speculation, the situation will get real bad in a hurry. The most populated and poor nations like India, Brazil, China, Egypt, Indonesia will have riots as the inflation and prices sky rocket. And it is not only food that matters, but rather fuel, water, housing, and other basic necessities that effect the poor, as compared to the decadent life style of the rich and their use, abuse, waste and indifference.

President Obama for a change needs to act now in issuing bans on commodities like wheat, corn, sugar, butter milk, poultry, beef fish, water, gasoline, natural gas, heating oil. electricity to be speculated and or traded the way they are. If the USA will implement these measures, Europe will follow suit.

There is something very wrong when bank credit cards can get 15% or even 21% interest, but if you put your savings in a bank you barely get 1.4% or so.  And should you be late with your credit card payment, then you can pay a penalty of $35.  Even with overdraft protection on my bank account, Chase just announced that instead of the $1.00 that Washington Mutual used to charge,  they will charge $10.00 if you overdraft.  No wonder that the middle class cannot save.  We are back to the robber barons of yesteryear.
It is impossible to have a rubost middle class if most good paying jobs are outsourced or automated.

The american govt wants this. We are a consumer spending economy, so spend using debt don't save we have great plans like. ... For retirement.

I have yet to see any politician encourage people to save, and i mean now it's 0% interest but you won't lose your money. We used to get 10% in savings.

This all the govt in bed with Goldman and JP to keep the market liquid.

Have you ever heard anybody in CNn money talk risk versus reward. Don't pay off your mortgage invest you get more, what about risk, you lose more too.

Bad CNN bad money advisors and bad govt for the corporations and only for the corporations not people.

I save. I manage my own money and thank me not the pundits on CNN or NYT.

Study finance it's our religion if you don't study you'll all be suicide bombers killing your families
